111E PRESS CONFERENCE LOCATION TBD. BJK CENTER
INT/EXT. BILLIE JEAN'S CAR/COASTAL HIGHWAY. DAY. 48
87A CONT INT. HAWAII AIRPORT LOUNGE. DAY. 87A CONT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLIE JEAN KING's 29 year-old face, big on the screen, concentrating hard. We hear a grunt and the noise of a se A flash and Billie Jean has reached the ball, returned it The ball comes back, but she is across the court with lightning speed and putting every ounce of energy into th shot, returns it again. We are inside her head: only the sound of her furious breathing, the ball and the squeak of tennis shoes can be heard. Back comes the ball, again and again, each time, Billie J punches it back until.... .++The world crashes in: a sudden surge of applause and cheering. The focus on Billie Jean’s face finally relaxes into a huge smile of triumph.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE V/O
dialogues.text: Game, set and match to Miss King. She throws the racket high into the air and we see she is surrounded by thousands of fans applauding wildly. LARRY KING, Billie Jean’s husband, jumps onto the court a embraces her. Title: Battle of the Sexes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faceless, glass office building. Distant traffic and honking horns. Moving in on one of the many windows, we find... TV (v.0.) ...and Billie Jean King’s triumph in the US Open adds another Grand Slam to a list of titles that makes her the most successful woman player of all time and brings a phone call from a very special fan....

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 2
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...fifty-four year old BOBBY RIGGS, tennis racket in hand staring at the TV. On the TV, Billie Jean is on court holding up the trophy the US Open. The TV cuts to a boardroom where she is now talking on a speaker-phone to PRESIDENT NIXON.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Mister President.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT NIXON V/O
dialogues.text: I just wanted to congratulate you on your great successes this year and being the first sportswoman to earn over a hundred thousand dollars in a season.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mister President. Thank you very much, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: TV, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: With five Wimbledon titles, a French Open win and now a fourth US Open crown, the Old Lady as she is affectionately known on the circuit- shows no sign of hanging up her tennis shoes any time soon.... Bobby switches off the TV with a sigh. He bats a ball of scrunched up paper expertly into the trash, wanders back behind a large, largely empty desk. He sets the Newton's Cradle desk toy going, his eyes following it’s progress b and forth for a while. Snaps out of it. Presses the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Has that contract from Diemberger come in yet, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL 0/S
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Sir. I turned it around yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: You did?  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 4

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL 0/S
dialogues.text: Just needed a signature. Hope that was the right thing to do, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. Sure. Anything else come in?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL 0/S
dialogues.text: No, Sir. Sits back. Opens his desk drawer. Pulls out a pack of car Suddenly shoves them back in and slams the drawer as if burned. Presses the intercom again.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Mike, I think I'll take an early one.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL 0/S
dialogues.text: Very good, Sir. Bobby grabs his coat and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby hunches down the street. A bunch of kids on rollerskates, one of them with a boom- on his shoulder playing the Stones at full volume, speed past, knocking Bobby off the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Completely ignored, Bobby turns into a church and goes in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A semi-circle of chairs around a table in a side-chapel o the church. A rag-tag bunch of people- mostly men- are sitting. One of the men is telling a rambling story about gambling addiction. Bored, Bobby starts making fish faces with his mouth. A satisfying popping noise.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLERS ANON LEADER
dialogues.text: Would anybody else like to speak? sir? He's looking at Bobby. Bobby points at himself. Really? M He stands up. Sighs. Here we go.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: My name is Bobby and I am an addict.

dialogues.speaker: ADDICTS
dialogues.text: Hi, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: At least that’s what Priscilla says. My wife. Lovely lady. His face briefly shines and then he remembers. BOBBY RIGGS (CONT’D) She's gonna leave me unless I quit gambling. A couple of ‘we hear you, Bobby’s from the room.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Puzzles me, this word: gambling. Every time she gets the car out the garage Priscilla’s gambling big time. Never checks the mirror, sticks it in reverse, puts her foot down, straight out onto the highway. Jeez Louise, that’s gambling. But here I am. Gamblers Anonymous.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLERS ANON LEADER
dialogues.text: And what’s your point, Bobby

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: My point? Everybody gambles all the time. Life’s a gamble, right? That's the thrill of it: this way or that way, the yes or the no, the heads or the tails of being alive! Yet here I am and here you are, heads bowed, ashamed of ourselves. But that ain’t right. You fellas aren't here cos you're gamblers- we're all gamblers. You're here cos you're terrible gamblers. That's what the problem is. You lose, right? And you end up here. More ashamed nods from the Gamblers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I get it. But there’s one thing worse than losing, friends: it’s not being in the game. If you’re not in game, what’s the point? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 6-7

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re dead men walking, right? I mean, look at us! This is taking a surprising turn. Even Bobby is cheering

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Heads up, fellas, we can turn this around, we can get back in the game, we will get back in the game... Everyone's listening now. This isn’t the inspirational sp they were expecting, but they like it.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLERS ANON LEADER
dialogues.text: I’m not sure that-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: I play a bit of cards, but sports is my bag: tennis, golf, shooting hoops, whatever it is, there’s a bet to made. And if there isn’t I don’t get out of bed. I hear you guys yammering on, and I realized. I see the problem. What you gotta do is get yourselves a thing.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLER
dialogues.text: A thing?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Yeah, a thing! An edge, an angle, the inside track, the sniff in the wind, the thing that turns you from a gambler to a hustler, from a loser to a winner. A thing!

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLERS ANON LEADER
dialogues.text: This is not what we should be talking about here.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Why do you want to stop us doing the one thing we really love? The Leader is nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: sir, all they gotta do is learn to do it better. Now, who’s dealing? He throws a pack of cards on the table, rolls up his slee

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Isn’t this fun?  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 6-78 7 INT. NEW YORK HOTEL ROOM -- BEDROOM/BATHROOM. EVENING. A silver trophy on the bedside table, surrounded by dozen FLOWER ARRANGEMENTS. Billie Jean’s husband LARRY KING (28 tall, immaculately dressed) reads the cards that came wit the flowers. Billie Jean is out of sight in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Flowers from your parents! We should have them over when we get back to California. A home-cooked meal, wouldn’t that be something? Billie Jean? In the bathroom, in a long evening gown, Billie Jean is putting on earrings. She is lost in her own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should go. Car’s here. Billie? He goes into the bathroom. Billie-Jean is just staring.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Billie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: can we not go?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Not go? You're the champ, honey. You're guest of honor! Then he sees that she’s serious.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It isn’t working, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You and me. Us. Being married. We're never in the same place at the same time and when we are, we don’t make each other happy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m happy. And if there’s more I can do to make you happy, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It’s not you, Larry. You know it’s not. Larry comes up to her and takes the necklace from her. St to put it on.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 6-7B

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: We've had our moments- which marriage doesn’t- but we’ve got through them before and we'll get through them again. The necklace is tied. LARRY (CONT’D) There. You look beautiful. A bit tired maybe which is hardly a surprise. Stop winning everything, honey. A weary smile from Billie.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow you're staying in bed and I’m doing everything, okay?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. You’re a good man, Larry King. He offers her his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Come on. They can’t start the dancing without you.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 8 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tournament Ball. Larry and Billie Jean alone on the d floor, waltzing elegantly- the perfect, happy couple. The are surrounded by hundreds of people in evening dress, al whom applaud as the song comes to an end. Larry kisses Bi Jean and welcomes the rest of the party-goers to join the the floor. GLADYS HELDMAN, a feisty forty-year old marches onto the floor, interrupting Billie and Larry.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Have you seen this??

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Gladys.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 9

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You want a dance?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: I want a gun. They've just snuck out this press release, the low- lifes. Gladys waves a piece of paper in front of Billie. Billie grabs it. Reads.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Which low-lifes?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Our so-called friends, the United States Lawn Tennis Association. Gladys jabs a finger at one particular line. Billie Jean’ eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What?! This is outrageous.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: It’s got Jack Kramer’s fingerprints all over it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely right. And I know where he’s hiding. Come on, Gladys. She grabs Gladys and they march off the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladys and Billie Jean walk between the tables.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: It’s a slap in the face, that’s what this is.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Slap on the wrist, more like. How dare we girls do so well?! Better put us in our place!

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: We can’t let them get away with it.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 10 9 INT. FOREST HILLS CLUB -- LIBRARY. EVENING. JACK KRAMER and BOB SANDERS are sitting in club chairs, relaxing. DANA, a young waitress, hands them whiskies.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Thank you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Sure, Mister Kramer. He follows the rear view with his eyes as she goes. Gladys and Billie Jean come marching in.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Surprised in their lair.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: An unexpected pleasure, ladies. You both look sensational, if I may say. GLADYS. You may not.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to be in here, you know-~

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: - because I’m a woman or a Jew?

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Oh, we have a Jewish member now. Don’t we, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: One black member as well.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Progress!

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: But no women.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: Not as yet, no. Jack pats a seat for Gladys, oblivious to the daggers sho his way.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: What can we do for you ladies? Glass of something?  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 ul Gladys sits, gets out a cigarette. Bob leans forward to l it. She pointedly lights it herself.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: I always find it’s best to be clear before committing cold-blooded murder, so, to clarify: the Pacific Southwest Tournament press release. She bangs the offending piece of paper down on the coffee table, rattling the china.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Ah. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It says you're offering twelve thousand dollars to the men’s winner and one thousand five hundred dollars to the women’s.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: That’s either a misprint or a provocation. I might get off with manslaughter.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: No, those are the terms.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: The men’s prize has to be that high to attract the best players. We're trying to make this the most prestigious tournament in America.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: And paying the women players less than ever makes it more prestigious. Aha. I get it. I see the logic. Hallelujah, my eyes have been opened.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: -Gladys. Said quietly but firmly. Everybody takes notice.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: You're lucky she’s here. She’s like the bomb disposal squad-

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: (firmer) - Gladys. A huff from Gladys. Silence.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 12

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I just bring it back around to the money, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: You know I’m sympathetic to your cause, Billie Jean. We've talked about this--

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: We have. Many times. You promised this year would be different.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: It's simply a question of what we can afford.

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: People come to see the men play. They’re the draw.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Eight times more of a draw?

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You're offering the men’s winner exactly eight times more than the women’s winner. Do we bring in an eighth of the crowd?

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: I don’t know the percentages--

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: They sold the exact same number of tickets today for the women’s final as the men’s final. Isn’t that right, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I suppose so. GLADYS. Same sales, same prize money. Seems fair to me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Be reasonable, there’s no way we can afford that.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 13

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Then what's your argument? Just give me a logical argument why you should pay a woman an eighth of what you pay a man and I promise I'll stop asking.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Well, for one thing, the men have to support their families.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm the main bread winner in my family.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Look. The men are simply more exciting to watch. They’re faster—-

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: -fact-

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: -stronger-

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: -fact-

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: -more competitive-

dialogues.speaker: BOB SANDERS
dialogues.text: -just a fact.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: It's not your fault. It’s biology.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: That's the best argument you've got? Really?

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: It's just the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: We'll boycott the tournament.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Fact.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: We'd sure miss your pretty faces, but...go right ahead.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 14 10 ql

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Not only will we boycott, we'll set up our own tournament. A flicker of panic from Gladys.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Fact.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: At the exact same time as the Pacific Southwest.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: um. Fact. Jack Kramer and Bob Sanders exchange a look. Jack smiles stands.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Well, be sure and send me tickets. You have a good night, ladies. He holds open the library door for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera follows Billie Jean and Gladys as they go.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Are we really going to do this?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Sure we're going to do this.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: How are we going to do this?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: No idea. INT. BOBBY’S HOUSE. EVENING. a An air of tension in this upscale dining room. Bobby, PRISCILLA his second wife and BOBBY’S SON are sitting at table.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Busy day?  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 15

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Run off my feet. Not a minute to think...Whatever it is I’m supposed to be doing there, Priscilla, I'm not doing it.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Daddy says you’re an integral part of the company.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Integral. Like the walls? The walk- in closet?

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: It’s steady. It’s what you need right now.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Did you go to- your meeting?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Only darned meeting I had. I might have to find another group.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: But you went.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Well done, honey. She smiles supportively at him. He attempts a smile back. Another silence. Bobby’s son peppers his food with a outs pepper grinder. Appraises it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S SON
dialogues.text: (sly) I wonder how much pepper corns are in here?

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: It’s not how much, it’s how many. And stop wondering. Or you can go wonder in your room.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S SON
dialogues.text: Mom...I was just asking Dad an educational question, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 16

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Oh, I...I dunno, Junior.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S SON
dialogues.text: I'd say ‘bout a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: (cracking) No way, there’s at least five thousand in there.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S SON
dialogues.text: I'd put a dollar on a thousand-

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: - young man! Bobby’s son gives the pepper grinder another provocative twist, winks at his Dad and mouths “one dollar”.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Absolutely not, young man. We do not gamble at the table.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: We do not gamble any place, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Exactly. Any place. Bobby pats his mouth with his napkin. Dabs at the sweat o his brow. Gets up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, honey, now I remember, there is something I need to do at the office.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Your Daddy put his faith in me. Don’t want to let him down. She smiles up at him uncertainly- benefit of the doubt.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Well, okay. Proud of you, honey. 12 EXT. TOWN TENNIS CENTER -- COURT. MANHATTAN. EVENING. Men's laughter, drinks, music. Wedges of greenbacks everywhere. In the middle of the table, surrounded by dollars, a set of car keys.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 17 Bizarrely, two Alsatians are bounding around a tennis cou Bobby on the end of their lead, being towed after them. O the other side of the net is JACK, retired business tycoo and amateur tennis player. Equally bizarre is the location of the court; on the flat roof of a skyscraper near the belching smoke stacks of th Con Edison Power Plant. Loving the show are the Boys: HANK, ex-baseball pro: reti KEN and gentle HERB, a tennis star in the 50’s, now in a wheelchair and LORNIE KUHLE, younger friend of Bobby’s an tennis pro. Somehow, Bobby manages to reach the ball and get it back the net. The Boys are loving it, the dogs are loving it a most of all, so is Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Dammit, Bobby....

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Teach them to serve and we could get them on the Circuit! Good boys, good boys go, go... He wins the point.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: A chair. C’mon, guys...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Two chairs and I'll raise you both five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: KEN/ HERB
dialogues.text: Done. Take him, Jack! Lornie rushes two chairs onto Bobby's side of the court t he now has to dodge around with the dogs. Chaos. Bobby is leaping over the chairs, getting the lead tangled in the legs...and yet somehow, the ball keeps being returned. More dollars are put down on the table by the Boys. There big money on this game. A fierce exchange of shots, culminating in a lot of barki and a massive lob from Bobby. Everyone watches its progre high into the sky and then down on the baseline. Right on baseline. Jack scrabbles back for it. Doesn't get there. Bobby leaps the net, shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Good game, Jack.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 18

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Dammit, I thought I had you this time, Bobby, I really did. Dejected, he walks off. The boys watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: He keeps betting me. What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thing about Jack is- he can afford to lose. Jack gets the car keys from the bowl in the middle of the table. Throws them to Bobby. Towels his face down.

dialogues.speaker: LORNIE
dialogues.text: What’s Priscilla going to say, Bobby? That’s what you gotta ask yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Don't spoil it, Jack, you know?

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: Priscilla? You still married, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: He sure will be if he turns up in a Rolls Royce.

dialogues.speaker: LORNIE
dialogues.text: He sure won't be if he turns up in a Rolls Royce.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: Whadd’ ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: LORNIE
dialogues.text: You think Priscilla won't know where it came from? Even Bobby's gonna find it hard talking that one away. “Hi, honey, this guy on the corner just gave me a Silver Shadow...” Think that'll cut it?

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: What’s to talk away? You've just won a damned Rolls Royce.

dialogues.speaker: LORNIE
dialogues.text: Herb, Bobby doesn’t gamble anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: You don’t?  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 19

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS

dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t get involved in politics. I’m certainly no women's libber. I’m just looking forward to a good game of tennis. TV SCREEN. We cut to an excited TV Commentator.

dialogues.text: ...this match has really gripped the nation. Suddenly a simple tennis game has become so much more. This, ladies and gentlemen has come to define the oldest of battles: man versus woman. And a question for our commentator today, Jack Kramer, where’s your money? On mankind or womankind? The camera pans to Billie’s nemesis: Jack Kramer. 73 78 79

dialogues.speaker: 79C
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 74

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, Bobby Riggs, without a doubt. Margaret Court is a great player, no mistake, but the thing about women is- they just can’t handle pressure. Just not built for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aeroplane sits on the tarmac as passengers deplane. Th Nine are trying to hustle through the crowd down the step from the aeroplane. Billie Jean is trailed by Marilyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sedate lines of travellers wandering slowly through the Arrivals area.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It’s starting! Out of nowhere, a horde of women in tennis whites charge through, side-stepping passengers, dodging cleaners and sleepy officials.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Virginia Slims, coming through! They charge onwards leaving a trail of bemusement behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret comes down the bleacher stairs onto the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girls are crowded around an area of tiny, black and w pay TV’s. They are perched two to a seat, using three or televisions. Everybody is shouting at Rosie to put more quarters in each of them.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I’m doing it, I’m doing it!  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 15

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Okay, shut up. Everybody shut up. She turns to the entire bustling airport lounge and yells

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can we have some quiet here, please? The entire airport obeys. On TV, the camera pans across t packed bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. This is big.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Course it’s big. It’s Bobby. One thing that man can do is hustle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the TV we see Margaret standing on the court. Bounces ball. Twirls her racket. Looks around a little lost. Wher Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: Do we like the dress?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It’s one of Ted’s. Are we allowed not to?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Right behind you, darling.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: We love the dress.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: She looks spooked to me.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m not liking this. Without taking her eyes off the screen, Rosie holds out h hand to Gladys.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gladys, cigarette.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 76 85 86

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Finally, one of my girls smokes! Somebody ring American Tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: We should’ve been there. You know, to support her. GLADYS. You got a tournament to play. I own you, Peaches. Anyway she doesn’t want your support. Doesn’t even like you.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Really? Gladys? Really?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: The Arm’s gonna be fine. She could squeeze the life outta that little twerp with one tweak of her bicep.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER 0/S
dialogues.text: And here he is, Male Chauvinist Pig of the Year, the man to beat, Bobby Riggs! GLADYS. Look at him. Like a frog with constipation.

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: What's he carrying? They peer at the fuzzy black and white image. There’s his racket in one hand and something else in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby comes down the stairs carrying a bunch of red roses casual as you like. Jogs over to Margaret and hands her t roses. She curtsies shyly.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And what better gift on Mother's Day, than a bunch of red roses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean puts her hands over her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna kill him.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 17

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: I’m gonna kill her. She shoulda stuffed those roses where the thorns mean business. What is she thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Umpire gets out a coin. Tosses it into the air. The c tumbles.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Who wants to call it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Ah-ah. Come on, Umpire, where’s your manners? It’s Mother's Day. Ladies first. Your choice, Margaret, and my pleasure. I may as well take this end, okay? And before anybody can complain, Bobby is jogging to the line. Margaret takes up position.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Missus Court to serve. Quiet please, ladies and gentlemen. A hush settles over the crowd. Margaret serves hard, but Bobby takes all the power off it with a slice. She return again, stays at the net. This time Bobby hits a high lob. Margaret gets under it, but the sun is in her eyes. White orange pain of staring directly at the sun. The ball is i and out of vision. She connects, but it is out. A little smile from Lornie in the stands. Margaret rubs h eyes. Tries to focus.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: The sneaky son-of-a...That’s why he chose to play at midday.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Right into the sun. He’s gonna lob her to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 78 Margaret Court being undone by Bobby. Short shots, spin shots, slice after slice, lobs right into the sun.

dialogues.speaker: 87A CONT INT. HAWAII AIRPORT LOUNGE. DAY. 87A CONT
dialogues.text: 88 89 90 The Nine huddled around the TV screens, a look of shock o their faces. Ted is fanning himself with a menu, a pictur horror.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Game to Mister Riggs. Mister Riggs leads one set to nothing. Change ends, please. They switch sides, Bobby smoothly taking a broad-brimmed from Lornie as he passes. Jams it on his head.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER V/O
dialogues.text: ++.as I said, it’s not that women can't play tennis, it’s just they can't deal with the pressure. Business, sport, politics, you name it. Whatever they like to think, at the very top, it’s a man’s world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an appalled stillness around the TV screens.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I'll give him pressure. Around the wind-pipe.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Wake up, Margaret, for god’s sake! He’s killing her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: He's already killed her. The moment she curtsied, right there, she was dead.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN. 90
dialogues.text: Lob after lob go up into the sun. Margaret misses them ti after time. The Umpire calls out the scores.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 79 91 92 92a 93

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Game, set and match to Mister Riggs. Mister Riggs wins 6-2, 6-1. Bobby leaps the net and gives a stunned Margaret a hug. T he steps back, points at somebody in the crowd. Runs over embraces Larry, his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the other side of the lounge, a group of men huddled around a radio at the bar let out yells and whoops of joy Silence around the TV screens as they watch Bobby strut around the court, arms raised in victory. Applause from t bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: That was- that was a massacre.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 92
dialogues.text: TV SCREEN. 92a Bobby is motor-mouthing to a throng of Reporters, his arm around Larry Riggs.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: This is my son, Larry. Lousy tennis player, great guy. Okay, so: Bobby Riggs is now officially the Number One Ladies player in the world. And if there’s any lady out there wants to challenge me to that crown, they know where to find me. In fact, let me put down that challenge myself. You know the Bobby Riggs motto: double or nothing. Well 1'11 do better. I won't just double it, I'll double the double. And then I'll double it again. Yes, Ma'am, one hundred thousand dollars to the woman who can beat me. But I ask myself, is she out there? And if she is does she dare? Bobby looking straight down the lens, right at....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .++Billie Jean, staring back.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 80

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: A hundred thousand dollars. Sheesh.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: There isn’t anything I don’t hate about Bobby goddam Riggs. Not one thing. Marilyn approaches, carrying two ice-creams. Holds one ou Billie Jean.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Not now. Furious, she gets up and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: What’s got to her?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Fate, honey. Coming at her like a runaway train.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 94
dialogues.text: 94m INT./EXT. MARGARET'S CAR/DESERT ROAD. DAY. 94m Tight-lipped, Barry drives Margaret. The radio is on.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: ...and in today’s much-publicised tennis face-off between Senior Pro, Bobby Riggs and Women’s Number One, Margaret Court, the self-styled Male Chauvinist Pig beat Mrs Court in straight sets, 6-2, 6-1 in what the press has dubbed ‘the Mother’s Day Massacre’- Barry switches off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET COURT
dialogues.text: Oh, for goodness sake. It was just a tennis match. She looks over at Barry.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET COURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wasn’t it? 95

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean is trying to wrap iced towels around her knee but is making a mess of it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: This isn’t tennis, it’s a soap opera. I don’t want anything to do with that!

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Then don’t.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: The women’s number one can’t beat a fifty-five year old?! Are you kidding me?? She just made women’s tennis look like a joke.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Nobody thinks you're a joke.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Hell, she just made women look like a joke.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Billie, since when did it become your job to defend the whole of womankind? Billie Jean pushes the ice packs off, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Who else is gonna beat him? Don’t you get it? I don’t have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: You always have a choice. Billie Jean grabs her racket and a bucket of tennis balls

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I need to think. She grabs her key and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 97
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 82 97a 98 99 100 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, Lornie and Larry sit in the only pool of light in vast, empty dining hall. At the table is a half-finished meal, a bottle of Scotch and beside him, a cart with a telephone on it. Ignored, Larry is watching Bobby obsessively play patienc Eventually, Larry gets up.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, I’1l- get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. And he goes back to his cards.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad, you really did it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: This? This was nothing. You wait, kiddo, you just wait. Larry waits for more, but Bobby has disappeared back into cards once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. One by one, the arc lights above the tennis cou come on. Billie Jean carries a bucket of balls onto the court. She starts serving. And serving and serving. INT. BILLIE JEAN’S HOTEL ROOM. HAWAII. NIGHT. 99 From the balcony, Marilyn watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean makes a call from a pay phone in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT., (INTERCUT)
dialogues.text: The phone rings in the dark bedroom. Larry wakes up, turn a light. Discombobulated. He answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hello?  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 83

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Larry, I’m sorry to call so late, but I need you and it can’t wait.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Quit apologizing. We're married, you can call any time. What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Bobby Riggs beat Margaret Court.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I was watching. It was a travesty.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You think I can beat him, right?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Riggs? In a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Then call the bozo. Tell him it’s on. But nothing gets agreed on without my approval. Venue, date, TV rights. Everything. Which balls we use. I know Bobby, he‘ll be doing deals on his deals by now.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’ll reach out first thing in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: No, now. He calls me at midnight. If we’re going, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Billie Jean? You know the press are going to be all over you, right?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: About everything?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Larry. I know. Let’s do this.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: All right. I'll call him now. Get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Larry? Thank you.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 84

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: This. And everything else.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Do anything for you. You know that. (Beat) Good night, Billie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Night, Larry. They hang up. Billie Jean stands there for a moment, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in the canteen, Bobby is still playing Patience. Th phone rings. He searches in his pockets until he finds wh he’s looking for- a hearing aid. Puts it in his ear and snatches up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Larry!...Sleeping? No, no, we got a party going on here! To the victor, the spoils, right? He waves the phone around vaguely in an attempt to create some atmosphere...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You spoke to Jerry? You should. He’s the man. Uhuh, uhuh- of course we'll agree, you know me, I’m a gentleman...Well, that’s just great news, Larry. Great news. Send my love to Billie Jean. He puts down the phone, puts up both arms in victory.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright! Alright! An echo. He looks around. BOBBY RIGGS (CONT’D) Maybe some dessert? Hello? The hello reverberates around the empty hall.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 103
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean opens the door. Marilyn is packing her bag.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Don't like to stay where I’m not wanted. Billie Jean sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Come here. Marilyn keeps packing. BILLIE JEAN (CONT’D) Please stop. Look at me. Marilyn looks at her, arms held across her chest.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not that I don’t want you here. The opposite, actually. Billie searches for the right words.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just not safe for me to carry on like this. I’ve decided to play Bobby. And the scrutiny I'll be under... I can’t risk people finding out.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: So, what? You're going to stay with Larry and keep pretending for the rest of your life? Billie Jean looks down, trying to gather her strength.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Billie? Do I or do I not make you happy?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: ..-It’s not about me right now. It isn’t even about tennis. This is a chance to do something that could really change things, something everyone will take notice of. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 86 105

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not just a few sports fans. Everyone. (Beat) I can’t let my personal business get in the way of that. Do you understand? After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: «++I hope you have a happy life, Billie Jean. I really do. She starts to pack again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to go right now. at least stay the night.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: No. I can't. Marilyn continues packing. Billie Jean watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn drags her suitcase down a long hallway. INT. HOTEL. BILLIE JEAN'S ROOM. HAWAII. SIMULTANEOUS. 105

dialogues.speaker: 105A
dialogues.text: 106 Billie Jean sits on the bed, alone, processing what happe EXT. BOBBY’S HOUSE. DAY. Priscilla opens the door. Bobby stands there.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Bobby's back!

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Exactly what I was afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Attagirl! Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Would it make it any difference if I said no? She gives up and walks into the house. 107  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 87 108 INT. BOBBY’S HOUSE. SITTING ROOM. DAY. 108

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Okay. Say what you want to say.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: I’m on top again. I’ve never felt better. Fresh as a daisy. Barbecued Margaret Court and now I’m playing Billie Jean, for a hundred thousand dollars. How about that? ABC is showing it- prime time. It’s huge.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: You've got a nerve with that male chauvinist pig nonsense. Who’s been bankrolling you all these years, Bobby Riggs? Me. A woman.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: You know what, you're absolutely right. And now I can pay you back. Isn't that fantastic?

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: I don’t want it back.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Do you want me back? A jolt. As ever, he’s caught her on the hop. BOBBY RIGGS (CONT’D) Larry’s been staying with me, you know? Helping out with the training. He’s all grown up. Great kid. He and Junior, maybe, could, y’know, hang out some. Be a family. Priscilla stares at him, considering.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jerry Perenchio’s puffing it up like you wouldn't believe. I'm gonna be on the front cover of Time Magazine- I won the triple at Wimbledon and I never got the cover of Time- and when I’ve beaten Billie Jean, Jerry’s put a million dollars on the table for a match against Chrissy Evert... He’s moving from boasting to fearful. BOBBY RIGGS (CONT’D) A million dollars!  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 88 He stops.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A million dollars. And then what? Priscilla, it’s a kinda scary ride I’m on. I, well, I need you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: We've been here before, Bobby

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: No, I’m a whole new person, now. Ask the shrink.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Voila! What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Nothing. He just gave me thirty dollars. Bobby looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What he owed you for your last game of black jack.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah, he was a terrible player. Priscilla laughs, shakes her head. Bobby laughs too- caug but there’s a chance. BOBBY RIGGS (CONT’D) Right?

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Bobby, I love you. Every since I met you, you've made me laugh. Your crazy ideas, your schemes, your dreams, your scams...You fill any xoom you walk into. God, I miss that. But I need a husband, sweetheart, someone steady, a man I can rely on. And that’s just not you. That’s okay, it’s more than okay, it’s wonderful. You've got to be who you are. But I can’t be it with you. Not anymore. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: No, I’m sorry. Goodbye, Priscilla.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 89 He turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Good luck with the match. He waves a hand, but doesn’t turn round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is on the payphone. He wipes away what looks suspiciously like a tear, puts on his best smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Jimmy! Bobby here. How’s it going, kiddo? Never better, never better. What are the odds right now....? Put fifteen grand on me to win, buddy. You heard me, fifteen big ones. He puts the phone down.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD K SMITH
dialogues.text: In other news, another battle in the never ending war of the sexes. This one on the tennis court for 100,000 purse... women’s tennis champion Miss Billie Jean King who is 29 accepted the challenge of 55 year old Bobby Riggs, the match to be held the time and place still to be decided. Miss King said she will not play for the money but in her words to put women’s tennis and women's lib back where it belongs. Riggs said he issued the challenge because I wanna prove women are lousy and they don’t belong on the same court as the men.

dialogues.speaker: LOCATION TBD. PRESS CONFERENCE. DAY. 110
dialogues.text: Bobby and Billie Jean enter from opposite ends of a long table covered with press microphones. They meet in the middle and shake hands. Photographers and Journalists cat this first prematch meeting. Bobby, intimidatingly close, chattering away like a madma  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 90

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Don’t get me wrong, I love women. In the bedroom and in the kitchen. But now they want to be everywhere. Where will it end? Pretty soon us boys won't be able to have an evening of cards, go to the game, go fishing, have a drink after work...because that’s what Women’s Lib really means. Well, it’s got to stop. And Bobby Riggs is the man to stop it. This, ladies and gentlemen, is Custer’s Last Stand- He turns to Billie and mumbles out the corner of his mout

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - you're gonna love this one- At the top of his voic

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - the Lobber versus the Libber! Points at Billie who despite herself bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Keep on talking, Bobby. The more nonsense you spout, the worse it’s going to be when you lose.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: I’m the Ladies Number One. The champ. Why would I lose?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Because dinosaurs can’t play tennis. 110A EXT. ‘TOWN TENNIS CENTER -- COURT. MANHATTAN. DAY 11 Larry waits on the court. Bobby appears dressed as Little Peep, a trail of photographers and hangers on behind him. Lornie is the only one looking less than pleased.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Sure. Little Bo Peep got’s a helluva slice on her. Come on, I’11 give you 40. You lose you buy the drinks. Larry exchanges looks with Lornie who just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: 110E
dialogues.text: THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 91

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Attaboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean running along the waterline, camera pans to reveal a news crew moving along side her, shooting out of van. TV SCREEN. 110c Beginning of a 60 minutes story

dialogues.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
dialogues.text: At the age of 55 most people's dreams of glory are far behind them. But Bobby Riggs sees a pot of gold and glory just over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priscilla and junior watch the 60 minutes segment.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
dialogues.text: We caught up with Bobby Riggs in Las Vegas. It seemed like a fitting place... Money changing hands. Going into Bobby’s pocket. (At BUK center)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE WALLACE
dialogues.text: Do you do it for the money?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS V/O
dialogues.text: Nah, I do it for fun, I do it for sport, it’s the thing to do. If I can't play for big money, I play for little money. If I can’t play for little money, I stay in bed. Sometimes on my own.

dialogues.speaker: 111A
dialogues.text: THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priscilla sitting at home watching Bobby on TV. She glanc over at Bobby's son who is enjoying his father’s jokes.

dialogues.speaker: PRISCILLA
dialogues.text: Really? I mean, really? Walks over to the TV and switches him off.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S SON
dialogues.text: Mom... 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean on court, putting herself through a punishing work-out of kangaroo jumps, press-ups and sit-ups. EXT. BETTY GRABLE’S HOUSE. TENNIS COURT. LA. DAY. 111 An empty tennis court. Lornie and Larry Riggs stand there waiting. He hits a few desultory balls across the net. We follow him out of the court, down the steps to the pool. EXT. BETTY GRABLE’S HOUSE. POOL. LA. DAY. 111A A couple of women float in the pool. Poolside, an entoura of Angelenos are drinking cocktails. Bobby is on a lounge cigar in hand, holding court. Larry Riggs passes them all, stands in front of his Dad.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Dad, I thought we were practicing.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: What I have to say to that? Six- two, six-one. Who needs to practice when I’m women’s Number One? And I've got a secret weapon. Rheo Blair, meet the most important person in my life. Apart from me. My son, Larry. Larry shakes hands with the impeccably coiffured Rheo.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell him, Rheo.

dialogues.speaker: RHEO BLAIR
dialogues.text: Two words, Larry. Super Nutrition.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 93 1118 He points to a tray on which there are dozens of small saucers, each containing colored pills.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You taking all these?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Four hundred a day.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: I’m rattling, but feeling better than ever.

dialogues.speaker: RHEO BLAIR
dialogues.text: The A to Z of Amino Acids. Vitamins, Protein pills, Fat Busters and some of Rheo’s Specials.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And what’s in those? Rheo takes a long, LA look at Larry.

dialogues.speaker: RHEO BLAIR
dialogues.text: Specialness.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Forget training, I’m gonna live forever!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: = relax, did I not slam Margaret into the ground? And she beat Billie Jean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie is sprinting from side of the base line to the oth bending and touching the white line each time. Larry coun the reps.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight, twenty-nine, thirty. She stops, exhausted. Pours water over her head.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 94 11ic EXT. FRONT OF BETTY GRABLE HOUSE. DAY. 1lic Bobby stands in front of a news crew.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: It’s like being reincarnated. This is the greatest thing I’ve ever done. Bigger than winning Wimbledon, Forest Hills, bigger than the pro-tour. This is the highlight of my career. Maybe my life.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES PRESENTER
dialogues.text: Your life?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: I'm sitting here with you, aren't I? Take a compliment. Next question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A montage of Billie Jean and Bobby. Stills of Billie Jean Bobby arm-wrestling together. Billie Jean feeling Bobby’s bicep.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS V/O
dialogues.text: Worried? Look, she’s got no forehand, she’s a slice-and-net kinda player. Like all women, she’s emotionally fragile. She just won't be able to take the pressure.

dialogues.speaker: 111E PRESS CONFERENCE LOCATION TBD. BJK CENTER
dialogues.text: Back to the Press Conference on court. Billie Jean is laughing but there is tension in her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Look, he can talk all he likes. It’s one of the few things he’s good at. It doesn’t mean a thing. The only thing that counts- the one thing that will settle this- is the match. And who wins. That and nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts of balls coming out of the sky. Billie slams l after lob. Bends over exhausted.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 95 113 114 11s Quick cuts of Billie serving. Ball after ball. Sweat stre in her eyes. Larry watches, the other side of the net.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Out. Out. In. out. Billie throws the racket down.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Just give me a second. She bends over like she might throw up. Larry watches her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby being photographed, dressed as Henry VIIIth, a Play Bunny on each arm. He pulls his hearing aid out and hides in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Speak up, kiddo, I can’t hear you. With these two dolls on my arm, my heartbeat’s too loud in my ears.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS V/O
dialogues.text: ++.what do I think? Women should keep their biscuits in the oven and their buns in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is reclining on a chaise-longue. Naked. A photograp and an assistant bustle around taking shots.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Delicious. Just like you, honey. Bobby Riggs, putting the show back into chauvinism. INT. LOCKER ROOM. DAY. (STUB HUB CENTER) 11s Pre-tournament, some of the Virginia Slims Gang are limbe up in the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He really gave Margaret a beating.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 96 116 117 118 119

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: She played like an idiot. There's no comparison. Margaret folds. You know Billie, she loves pressure.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but her game's off right now.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It is. Hate to say it but my money’s on Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Mine too.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Money that you've got because of Billie Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: It’s not personal. I don’t want him to win. I just think he will. The rattle of a toilet door. Billie Jean comes out. Silen as she walks between them up to the basins, washes her ha and walks past them all and out into a barrage of cheerin and applause. The Girls look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Exactly what she needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lornie calls out to Bobby in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: LORNIE
dialogues.text: Bobby, Channel Seven! Bobby comes in from the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: What? Am I on? On the screen, we see a REPORTER live from Forest Hills.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 97

dialogues.speaker: SPORTSCASTER
dialogues.text: The breaking news from Forest Hills is that Billie Jean King has been defaulted in her third round match against Julie Heldman. Looking tired and dispirited, Miss King left the court after only one set, citing illness. Despite a press release reporting flu-like symptoms, speculation mounts that pressure from the upcoming match against Bobby Riggs is taking its toll.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Taking its toll, baby! I knew it. She’s crumbling. And I’m sitting by the pool. Now tell me about practicing. Flowers! We need to send her a bunch of flowers so goddam huge she can’t ever forget me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean is in bed. Gladys is smoking and pacing. Larr sits across the room.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Are you scamming me to get more practice time? Billie Jean pulls the thermometer out of her mouth to protest.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm sick!

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Lemme see that. She grabs the thermometer. Examines it.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, you're not dying.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Try to sound pleased.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I love the other girls- kind of- but you're my biggest draw. You're a giant.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 98

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: A giant with the flu. Gladys just stares at her. BILLIE JEAN (CONT’D) Gladys. I can’t eat. I can’t sleep. My knees hurt, my shoulders hurt, my chest hurts.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Your chest?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Like there’s a weight. Right here. She taps on her heart. Gladys sighs and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Okay. Take two weeks off. Go someplace. Practice, don’t practice, whatever you have to do. But you've got a tournament the day after this Riggs match and, win or lose, you're gonna be there.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Gladys. Gladys gets up and goes to the door. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: And just so you know. If you lose, I will never forgive you. She leaves. Billie Jean flops back on her pillow.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It’s too much pressure. Larry. No wonder my body's falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Billie? If there’s someone...you need...who you want me to call... I can call her. Beat. Billie Jean looks down.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: No. There’s no one. Thank you. Larry stands.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I've been thinking. There’s something I want to tell you.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 99 121 122 123 Billie Jean braces herself.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I love you. No matter what happens. On the court--or off. You hear me? They make real eye contact for the first time in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: ++ -Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is entertaining a host of journalists, playing tric shots through his legs, jumping over chairs, dressed in a rain cheater and hat...it is ridiculous but brilliant. Th isn't a shot he can't return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is playing doubles with his leg tied to another man leg. The crowd are loving it. A brief pause while a beautiful young woman hands him a cocktail. He takes it, blows her a kiss and takes a big s EXT. BETTY GRABLE’S HOUSE. TENNIS COURT. LA. DAY 123 TV News footage of Bobby on the court, this time with a b lion on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: .++and anyone who mistakes him for a fool may well end up looking like one. Whether he’s wearing a dress, playing with an umbrella or sporting these season’s must-have accessory-a lion cub- Bobby hasn’t lost a match yet. Footage of another player paying out dollar bills to Bobb who flashes a fan of them to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as the Bobby Riggs circus moves on to the next town, people are beginning to wonder what has happened to the opposition? Has she choked? Has she fled the country? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 100 124 125 126

dialogues.speaker: 126A
dialogues.text: 127 TV REPORTER (CONT’D) After withdrawing from Forest Hills with a virus, nobody has seen even the ghost of Billie Jean King. INT. GENE SHAWCOVE’S HAIR SALON. DAY. 124 A small TV set in the salon is playing the footage. Maril stares at the TV, ignoring the complex coloring operation is supposed to be performing. Bonny works next to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: It's not right. It’s just not right. She rips off her rubber gloves and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: HAIR CLIENT
dialogues.text: Hey! Where are you going? Marilyn keeps walking, right out the door.

dialogues.speaker: HAIR CLIENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is she going??

dialogues.speaker: BONNY
dialogues.text: My guess? Houston. INT. HOUSTON ASTRODOME. OWNER’S SUITE. DAY 125 JERRY PERENCHIO, ROONE ARLEDGE Head of ABC Sports and Bob sit in the palatial suite. We see the back of another man standing at the window. Silence. Bobby is jiggling his le nervously.

dialogues.speaker: ROONE ARLEDGE
dialogues.text: She did know what time-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: (snapping) - yes. Told you. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN. HOWARD COSELL AND BOBBY RIGGS 126A
dialogues.text: INT. HOUSTON ASTRODOME. OWNER’S SUITE. DAY 127 The guys are gathered around the TV watching a promo for broadcast.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 101

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD COSELL
dialogues.text: On Sept. 20, at the Houston Astrodome, 8pm Eastern Standard time it’s the Battle of the Sexes... But Mother Riggs what’s going to happen?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: I predict that I will lob her to death and chop her to death. She won't have a chance, I’m gonna psych her right out of her socks. They’re all enjoying the clip. Jerry checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY PERENCHIO
dialogues.text: Has she pulled out?

dialogues.speaker: ROONE ARLEDGE
dialogues.text: She was ill... Then the door bangs open and in strides Billie Jean, Rosi Cassals and Larry. Billie is tanned, fit, ready for battl

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Apologies, Gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Hey! How’s the flu, honey?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Flu?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Heard you were ill.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You don’t believe what you read in the papers, do you, Bobby? But thank you for the flowers. I gave them to Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I put them in the trash. Then Billie sees the figure standing at the window. Freez

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Jack? Jack Kramer who has been standing a little apart staring the window turns.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Billie Jean.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 102 Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What are you...?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Jack's my choice of commentator for ABC.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Jack? No. That won't work.

dialogues.speaker: ROONE ARLEDGE
dialogues.text: Now, Billie Jean, nobody's complaining about Rosie doing the Play by Play.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Rosie hasn’t single-handedly tried to dismantle women’s tennis.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: You overstate my influence, Billie Jean.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You black-balled us from the USLTA.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: He did you a favour. Lousy organization. Jack's my choice.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY PERENCHIO
dialogues.text: Sure make for a punchy commentary.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: No. I won't play.

dialogues.speaker: ROONE ARLEDGE
dialogues.text: Look, I've paid seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars for this event: you can’t turn up on the eve of the match saying you won't play.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: I wonder if we could have a word? Just the two of us. He gestures to the ante-room to the owner’s suite.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 103 128 INT. HOUSTON ASTRODOME. OWNER’S SUITE. ANTE-ROOM. DAY Jack Kramer and Billie Jean stand facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Billie Jean, I know we've had our differences, but that’s behind us. This is between you and Bobby now.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Bobby? Bobby’s a clown. The whole thing’s a big act for him. With you, it’s different. It’s for real.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: What do you mean.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Your dislike of women.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Happily married for thirty-two years. He spreads his hands? Go figure.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh, you like us well enough in the kitchen and the bedroom, bringing up the kids and doing the dishes. I bet you’re a real gentleman- and I mean that sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: I’ll take my compliments where I can from you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It’s when we dare to want more, just a little bit of what you’ve got. That’s what you can’t stand. And to have you up there, telling the American public what to read into every serve, every point? I’m sorry, Jack, but if you're commentating, I’m not playing. Jack drops the smile.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: How do you think that will make the great Billie Jean King look? Backing out at the last minute because she didn’t like the commentator?  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 104 129 130

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Pretty similar to how it would make the great Jack Kramer loo! shutting the whole thing down because he didn’t get to participate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalemate. Jack considers, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: No. This means too much to you. You and your Sisterhood. You'd never throw it over this.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Remember the last time you thought I was bluffing? One dollar. He stares at her for a moment. Points to her hands. They shaking.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KRAMER
dialogues.text: Know the difference between a good player and a great? The great players don’t let emotion get in the way. It messes with their game. He walks out. She gets up and follows him into the main r INT. HOUSTON ASTRODOME. OWNER’S SUITE. DAY 129 Jack walks straight past the waiting group.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sorry, Bobby. Billie Jean stands at the door, grips her hands together stop the shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gaggle of Camera Men and Reporters waiting at the doo leap to their feet as Billie Jean and Larry come out of t entrance and hurry towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Any last minute thoughts, Billie Jean? Are you going to win?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Of course she’s gonna win. The MALE REPORTER turns to his female colleague.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 105

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Not if it goes long. Women can’t handle five sets. Billie Jean stops. Turns to the Male Reporter.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Do you have a daughter? A sister? You sure as heck have a Mother. Is she not as good as your Father? Because she’s a woman? Do you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: But that’s what you’re saying. Whether you think you are or not. If I beat Bobby Riggs in five sets, will you stop saying it?

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: I- okay.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Sir, I’m going to hold you to that.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Billie- Larry takes her arm and hustles her into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean is walking up steps. She seems to be climbing forever upwards. Finally, she stops and turns. She is in very top tier of the Astrodome looking down on the massiv empty stadium. She sits and stares at the small patch of green in the ce that is the tennis court. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the TV Control Room, a tense hush. Jerry Perenchio looks on as the DIRECTOR and Vision Mixer are cutting bet cameras, exploring the shots. Over the radios.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 106

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: Thirty minutes to broadcast, sixty- five minutes to Game Time.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Zoom in, 4. Camera 2 and Camera 1. Wide on 5. Is that a Priest? Camera 5 finds a Priest in the stands standing between wh is clearly a Bride and Groom.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY PERENCHIO
dialogues.text: If Bobby wins, she takes the groom's surname. If Billie wins, the groom takes her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rheo, Lornie and Bobby’s Entourage heading out at speed. Bobby is gulping down handfuls of Rheo’s pills.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Okay, wagons roll! Let’s go, people, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is about to get on the escalator. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Larry. Where’s Larry? Larry! Larry comes out. BOBBY RIGGS (CONT’D) Come on.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna watch it here.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean, ‘watch it here’? I booked an entire Astrodome for you.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 107

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m not coming.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: You're afraid I’m gonna lose?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You don’t need me, that’s all. I thought you did, but you don’t. Good luck, Dad. He turns and goes back into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS
dialogues.text: Larry! He gives up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never understood that kid.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: ++.and we're live! And now, a real carnival atmosphere. Men in the crowds are wearing T-shirts proudly proclaimin themselves “Riggs Pigs”. Others wear bras and aprons. An equal number of women have banners supporting Billie Jean shirts with “I love Billie Jean” emblazoned on the front. Others are in ball gowns drinking champagne. You couldn't a more mixed crowd. Frank Gifford, ABC’s roving reporter, is out canvassing opinions. Various Pops: “I’m for Bobby”. “Billie’s gonna it". “I’ve got a hundred dollars on Bobby”... Everywhere, money is changing hands as the betting hots u Jimmy the Greek gives his opinion to Frank:

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY THE GREEK
dialogues.text: King money is scarce. It’s hard to find a bet on the girl. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 108

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY THE GREEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Court was number one and Bobby thrashed her. That’s the stats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie Jean stands in front of the mirror, wearing her te dress & a pair of BLUE SUEDE ADIDAS SHOES. She is surroun by Rosie, Ted, Henry, Larry, a nervous THIRD AD, and Bill Jean's PARENTS. Everyone seems to be talking at once.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (Reading telegrams) From Senator Macintyre. “Good luck, Billie Jean. We're all rooting for you.” Annie from New York- “go, Billie, we know you’re going to win...”

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (Fussing over her dress) You've lost weight. I need to take this in.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: We don’t have time.

dialogues.speaker: TED AND HENRY
dialogues.text: We've time. BILLIE JEAN’S DAD How are you feeling, honey? BILLIE JEAN’S MOM Do you need anything? Water?

dialogues.speaker: THIRD AD
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes to Game Time.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I have to ask: do you really intend to inflict blue suede shoes on ninety million members of the viewing public? BILLIE JEAN’S MOM How many? Goodness, Billie Jean...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: If they're good enough for Elvis, they’re good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Well something’s off, and I think it’s the shoes.  BATTLE OF THE SEXES - Simon Work File - 4/7/16 109

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It’s not the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Your hair. They turn and see Marilyn standing in the doorway. A froz moment. Then Billie Jean gathers herself:

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Mom. Dad. This is Marilyn. My hairdresser. BILLIE’S MOM Pleased to meet you. They shake hands. BILLIE’S DAD Well, if I know one thing, it’s to never get between a woman and her hairdresser. Come on, honey, let’s find our seats.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I'll take you up there. He puts a hand on Billie Jean’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
